conclusion: To determine when the two objects are farthest apart, analyze their relative motion using the velocity-time graphs provided.
The graphs show that both objects A and B start from the same location, move in the same direction, and their velocity (v) vs. time (t) relationships are depicted.
The displacement of an object equals the area under its velocity-time curve. To find when the objects are farthest apart, determine when the difference in their displacements is maximum.
Object A starts with velocity 0 at t = 0, increases linearly to velocity v₀ at time t₂, and decreases linearly back to 0 at time t₄.
Object B starts with velocity v₀ at t = 0, decreases following a curve until reaching 0 at time t₂, and increases following a curve until reaching v₀ at time t₄.
The objects are farthest apart when their relative displacement stops increasing, which happens when their velocities become equal.
The velocities of objects A and B are equal at two points: at time t₁ and at time t₃.
After t₁, Object A's velocity becomes greater than B's, so A starts catching up to B, reducing their separation.
After t₃, Object B's velocity becomes greater than A's, so B starts catching up to A, reducing their separation.

The objects are farthest apart at time t₃. At this point, their velocities are momentarily equal, and after this moment, their separation begins to decrease as Object B's velocity exceeds Object A's velocity.
